Using knitractive with Bash

Jeroen Janssens

2017-09-07

View the corresponding bash.Rmd file.

Set a variable

[/data]$ NAME=$(whoami)

Spread a pipeline over multiple lines

[/data]$ seq 100 |
> grep 3 |
> wc -l
19

Retrieve a value

[/data]$ cowsay "I am ${NAME}"
 ___________
< I am root >
 -----------
        \   ^__^
         \  (oo)\_______
            (__)\       )\/\
                ||----w |
                ||     ||

Command substitution

[/data]$ alias
alias l='ls -lph --group-directories-first'
[/data]$ mkdir test && cd test
[/data/test]$ curl -sL http://bit.ly/iris-csv > iris.csv
[/data/test]$ l
total 8.0K
-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 4.5K Sep  7 10:16 iris.csv
[/data/test]$ echo "Iris has $(< iris.csv wc -l) lines"
Iris has 150 lines
[/data/test]$ head iris.csv | csvlook
| SepalLength | SepalWidth | PetalLength | PetalWidth | Name        |
| ----------- | ---------- | ----------- | ---------- | ----------- |
|         5.1 |        3.5 |         1.4 |        0.2 | Iris-setosa |
|         4.9 |        3.0 |         1.4 |        0.2 | Iris-setosa |
|         4.7 |        3.2 |         1.3 |        0.2 | Iris-setosa |
|         4.6 |        3.1 |         1.5 |        0.2 | Iris-setosa |
|         5.0 |        3.6 |         1.4 |        0.2 | Iris-setosa |
|         5.4 |        3.9 |         1.7 |        0.4 | Iris-setosa |
|         4.6 |        3.4 |         1.4 |        0.3 | Iris-setosa |
|         5.0 |        3.4 |         1.5 |        0.2 | Iris-setosa |
|         4.4 |        2.9 |         1.4 |        0.2 | Iris-setosa |

Take a screenshot of htop 

[/data/test]$ apk update
fetch http://dl-cdn.alpinelinux.org/alpine/v3.5/main/x86_64/APKINDEX.tar.gz
fetch http://dl-cdn.alpinelinux.org/alpine/v3.5/community/x86_64/APKINDEX.tar.gz
v3.5.2-171-gb5b79ee2c8 [http://dl-cdn.alpinelinux.org/alpine/v3.5/main]
v3.5.2-168-g52b4d7b39a [http://dl-cdn.alpinelinux.org/alpine/v3.5/community]
OK: 7994 distinct packages available
[/data/test]$ apk add htop
(1/1) Installing htop (2.0.2-r0)
Executing busybox-1.25.1-r0.trigger
OK: 800 MiB in 169 packages
[/data/test]$ htop

After two seconds we see the following screen:

  1  [                          0.0%]   Tasks: 3, 0 thr; 1 running
  2  [                          0.0%]   Load average: 0.20 0.13 0.08
  Mem[||||||||||||||     2.65G/8.76G]   Uptime: 04:14:59
  Swp[                      0K/3.91G]

  PID USER      PRI  NI  VIRT   RES   SHR S CPU% MEM%   TIME+  Command
    1 root       20   0  1528     4     0 S  0.0  0.0  0:00.03 /bin/sh -c bash
    6 root       20   0  6220  1752  1476 S  0.0  0.0  0:00.01 bash
   28 root       20   0  3488  1104   844 R  0.0  0.0  0:00.00 htop












F1Help  F2Setup F3SearchF4FilterF5Tree  F6SortByF7Nice -F8Nice +F9Kill  F10Quit

Press F10 or q to exit htop.

Send interrupt

We can simulate pressing CTRL-C to quit long-running processes:

[/data/test]$ sleep 1000
^C

Create a file with vi 

[/data/test]$ vi example
[/data/test]$ cat example
this is a test
[/data/test]$ l
total 12K
-rw-r--r-- 1 root root   15 Sep  7 10:16 example
-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 4.5K Sep  7 10:16 iris.csv
